He shows how strong financial data isn't enough, and reveals why investors need to look at a company's environmental, social and governance structures, too.", "event": "TED@State Street Boston", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Chris McKnett: The investment logic for sustainability", "slug": "chris_mcknett_the_investment_logic_for_sustainability", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "1799", "slug": "chris_mcknett", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Chris", "lastname": "McKnett", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Sustainable investment champion", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/d5d08079410e87bf5a2251b61b15a8a6224f39d1_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "Chris McKnett helps institutional investors put money toward sustainable and socially-forward assets.", "whylisten": "

At State Street Global Advisors, Chris McKnett thinks deeply about how large investors, like banks, pension funds and endowments, can put their money in the right places -- not just for better business, but for a better world. In his role as the head of State Street Global Advisors' Environmental, Social and Governance Investing (ESG), McKnett develops sustainable-strategic products and integrates sustainability thinking directly into the investment process.

author: Chris_McKnett;
title: The investment logic for sustainability

aws-transcripts.transcript: the world is changing in some really profound ways, and I worry that investors aren't paying enough attention to some of the biggest drivers change, especially when it comes to sustainability. And by sustainability, I mean the really juicy things like environmental and social issues and corporate governance. I think it's reckless to ignore these things because doing so conjectured AJ's future long term returns. And here's something that may surprise you. The balance of power to really influence sustainability rest with institutional investors. The large investors like pension funds, foundations and endowments. I believe that sustainable investing is less complicated than you think. Better performing than you believe. And more important than we can imagine. Let me remind you what we already know. We have a population that's both growing and aging. If 7,000,000,000 souls today headed to 10,000,000,000 at the end of the century, we consume natural resource is faster than they could be replenished in the emissions that are mainly responsible for climate change. Just keep increasing now. Clearly, he's their environment on social issues, but that's not all their economic issues, and that makes some relevant to risk in return, and they are really complex, and they can seem really far off that the temptation maybe to do this, bury our heads in the sands and not think about it. Resist this if you can. Don't do this at home. But it makes me wonder if the investment rules hey, are fit for purpose. Tomorrow we know that investors, when they look at a company and decide whether it's to invest, they look at financial data metrics like sales growth, cash flow, market share, valuation.
